results.title: Big night
results.creator_credit: Stanley Tucci, Campbell Scott, Jonathan Filley, Rysher Entertainment and Timpano Productions
results.brief_description: A treat for movie and food lovers everywhere, this multi-award winning comedy tells the story of two Italian brothers (Primo and Secondo), whose superb restaurant is on the brink of bankruptcy. Their only chance is to risk everything they own on one big night where they invite local identities and band leader Louis Prima to a six course, twenty-two dish feast that will either make or break them. Cast includes Ian Holm, Tony Shalhoub, Stanley Tucci, Isabella Rossellini and Minnie Driver.

results.title: Big lies of the 20th Century
results.creator_credit: Tomasz Malinowski, Michael Jones, Channel Four and Panoptic Productions
results.brief_description: An examination of some of this Century’s significant acts of censorship. The emphasis of the program is how film has been manipulated to support political propaganda including Nazi Germany, the Vietnamese Conflict, during Stalin’s reign in the Soviet Union and the anti-communist trials in the United States. This is an invaluable program for showing how history and the media can conspire to make the process of seeking the truth more difficult.

results.title: Big Bill: the story of a heron
results.creator_credit: Hugh Miles, Anthony Bomford and RSPB Film and Video Unit
results.brief_description: This beautifully photographed film looks at one of the most well-known water-birds, the grey heron. Habitat, nesting, breeding, raising the young and collecting food are aspects of the heron’s life that are examined. Narrated by Eric Thompson.

results.title: Big brother of Christmas Island: Tai Ko Seng [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Mathew Kelley, Samantha Kelley, Peter Du Cane and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This documentary explores the significant role Gordon Bennett played in the development of the union movement on Christmas Island. Bennett immigrated from England to Australia and quickly rose in the union ranks. In 1979 he arrived at Christmas Island to help the workers union improve worker conditions. He was responsible for significant changes and during his twelve years became a folk hero to the local inhabitants.

results.title: Big boys don't cry
results.creator_credit: Tee Bosustow and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description: A young boy wanders through bushland enjoying nature’s beauty. Carrying a slug gun he initially shoots at a paper cup, however images of TV western gunfights go through his mind and on impulse he takes aim and shoots a bird. Realising what he has done the boy runs away as scenes of real life violence flash before him - scenes of war and innocent killing. The boy makes the decision to return to target shooting. A non-verbal film with b&w sequences. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Bhowani Junction
results.creator_credit: George Cukor, Pandro S. Berman and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: In what is considered by many fans to be her best performance, Ava Gardner stars as the heroine Victoria Jones, a woman forced to make some painful life decisions in post Colonial India. Her relationship with three men; Colonel Savage (Stewart Granger) a British military man in charge of protecting trains crossing Bhowani Junction, fellow Anglo-Indian Patrick Taylor (Bill Travers), and Sikh communist Peter Illing who befriends Victoria after she kills a potential rapist in self defence - challenging her to assess where her loyalties and ethnicity lie. Adapted from the novel by John Masters.

results.title: Beyond the rift wall
results.creator_credit: Charlotte Gobeil, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Canadian International Development Agency
results.brief_description: A film about a group of farmers and their wives who went to live and work among the Tanzanians, training them in Canadian methods of grain growing and production. It examines the cultural effects of this exchange both on the Canadians, who found themselves isolated by geography and language, and on the Tanzanians who were exposed to Canadian work habits and technology.

results.title: Beyond the naked eye
results.creator_credit: Claudia Overing, Francois Seguillon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film of marvels, an amazing view of the living, pulsing universe contained in a single drop of water from a fish aquarium. Colour film and a microscope, and the infinite patience of the filmmakers, reveal life that no-one would ordinarily see. This is a view of creation, of birth, life and death, of the laws of nature that apply even to the smallest of living things. It is a film that will add knowledge and insight to the pleasure of any audience. Photographers: Eric Chamberlain, Claudia Overing. Narrated by Sharry Plett and Albert Martin. Awards: Tehran; Belgrade; Melbourne.

results.title: Beyond the frame (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: B.Z. Vincent-Batyka, Tate Gallery and Royal College of Art (Great Britain)
results.brief_description: In attempting to break down the barriers between art galleries and the general public, the Tate Gallery gives lectures to groups of adults and is involved in a special program for children, called Kid’s Play, to help them appreciate the different types and forms of art.
results.creator_credit_for_label: B.Z. Vincent-Batyka, Tate Gallery and Royal College of Art (Great Britain)

results.title: Beyond reason
results.creator_credit: Telly Savalas, Howard W. Koch, Arthur M Sarkissian and Allwyn Pictures Corp
results.brief_description: Well-known TV actor Telly Savalas stars in “Beyond Reason”, the only film he wrote and directed. “Beyond Reason” is an intriguing exploration into the relationship between doctor and patient and the degree of humanity that is normally allowed in this relation. Savalas plays Dr. Nicholas Mati, a psychiatrist in a mental hospital with a very unconventional approach to his patients. In fact, the film opens with a high-energy sequence in which a group of men are gambling with dice; it only becomes clear later that this group comprises a doctor and his patients. This underscores Mati’s ‘eccentric’ approach toward psychic recuperation, he favours love, warmth and compassion over clinical distance; an approach, however, which gets him into conflict with his superior, makes some of his colleagues uncomfortable and even confuses his students during lectures. Above all, Mati is shown to treat his patients as ‘humans’, and with exactly the same warmth and affection with which he relates to his family and friends in the ‘normal’ world. However, a gnawing sense of anxiety and paranoia leads the doctor to a crisis of confidence, triggered when one of his students questions his particular philosophy. A series of delusions and imaginings in which his approach is questioned and mocked culminates in hallucinatory madness, and it’s not until then that the doctor breaks through his crisis and re-gains a position of normality and confidence. “Beyond Reason” affirms its pro-humanity stance when it suggests how easily we can all slip into madness and how important understanding and sensitivity are at such times. Cast also includes Diana Muldaur, Laura Johnson and Marvin Laird.
